document_title: Simulated Microgravity Induces Regionally Distinct Neurovascular and Structural Remodeling of Skeletal Muscle and Cutaneous Arteries in the Rat
summary_full: This study investigated the effects of hindlimb unloading (HU), a model for simulated microgravity, on small arteries in different regions of the rat. After two weeks of HU, forelimb skeletal muscle arteries showed increased lumen diameter and contractile responses, while hindlimb skeletal muscle arteries exhibited decreased diameter and contractility. Forelimb cutaneous arteries were largely unaffected, whereas hindlimb cutaneous arteries (saphenous) showed increased sensitivity to vasoconstrictors and reduced sympathetic innervation density, leading to impaired sympathetically induced vasoconstriction. These findings suggest that simulated microgravity induces complex, region-specific vascular remodeling, with skeletal muscle arteries primarily affected by mechanical forces and cutaneous arteries by changes in sympathetic nerve influence due to altered transmural pressure. These adaptations may explain reduced vascular responsiveness observed in astronauts.
key_findings: Hindlimb unloading (HU) increased lumen diameter and contractile responses in forelimb skeletal muscle arteries.
HU decreased lumen diameter and contractile responses in hindlimb skeletal muscle arteries.
HU increased sensitivity to vasoconstrictors in hindlimb cutaneous arteries (saphenous) but not skeletal muscle arteries (sural).
HU reduced sympathetic innervation density in hindlimb cutaneous arteries.
HU impaired sympathetically induced vasoconstriction in hindlimb cutaneous arteries.
Vascular adaptations to HU are region-specific, differing between skeletal muscle and cutaneous beds, and between forelimbs and hindlimbs.
future_research_fields: Investigating the specific molecular mechanisms underlying the differential remodeling of skeletal muscle versus cutaneous arteries.
Determining the role of nerve growth factor (NGF) and other trophic factors in mediating sympathetic nerve changes.
Exploring countermeasures to prevent or mitigate these region-specific vascular adaptations during spaceflight.
Further characterizing the pre-junctional changes in neurotransmitter release during sympathetic nerve activation in HU conditions.
Examining the long-term effects of HU on vascular structure and function, and the potential for recovery upon return to normal gravity.
conclusions: Simulated microgravity (hindlimb unloading) induces contrasting structural and functional adaptations in forelimb and hindlimb skeletal muscle arteries, primarily driven by mechanical forces. In the hindlimb, cutaneous arteries exhibit altered sensitivity to vasoconstrictors and reduced sympathetic innervation, suggesting that changes in transmural pressure significantly impact neurovascular control. These findings provide a mechanistic link between microgravity-induced pressure changes and impaired sympathetic vascular control, potentially contributing to orthostatic intolerance upon return to Earth.
impact_statement: This study reveals region-specific vascular remodeling in response to simulated microgravity, highlighting differential effects on skeletal muscle and cutaneous arteries, which has implications for understanding cardiovascular deconditioning in astronauts and developing countermeasures.
